floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are rising on the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream due to Storm Ciaran. Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Flooding is possible today, 02/11/2023. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon. River levels are rising. We are checking weed screens in the area. Our incident rooms are open and we are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. We are aware that some river level telemetry data are not appearing or being updated on the gov.uk website. We are sorry about this and are working hard to resolve this as soon as possible. This fault is not affecting our operational response. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 03/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible from late Wednesday evening 1st November, and into Thursday morning. 

Heavy rain falling in Devon due to Storm Ciaran has caused the River Exe to start rising. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to local rivers from around 10:30pm on Wednesday evening is possible. 

Flood Warnings may be required. Please take care near the areas of concern. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Tone from Bathpool to Ham including Ruishton and Creech St Michael, riverside properties
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Tone due to Storm Ciaran.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Ham Mills at Coalharbour Bridge.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon. River levels shall remain high at the Bishops Hull and Taunton Market gauges.
We have deployed the temporary pump in the Bathpool area. Consider activating any property flood protection products. 
Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We are aware that some river level telemetry data are not appearing or being updated on the gov.uk website. We are sorry about this and are working hard to resolve this as soon as possible. This fault is not affecting our operational response. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 03/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We expect river levels to remain high on spring tides until at least 05/11/23. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 03/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dauntsey Brook at Dauntsey, Old Sodom Lane and The Green areas
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Dauntsey river gauge as a result of Storm Ciarán. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are riverside properties on Old Sodom Lane, The Green and Dauntsey Green including Earl Danbys Primary School. Sodom Lane and the area around the Providance Chapel. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to begin falling at 20:00 on 02/11/23.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 03/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 09:20 PM on 02/11/2023.
Areas most at risk include Lyme Regis, Charmouth, Seatown, West Bay, Bothenhampton, Burton Freshwater, Burton Bradstock, Cogden Beach, Chesil Beach, West Fleet, East Fleet and Chiswell.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is dry for overnight.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Yarty from Yarcombe to Axminster
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Heavy rain falling in the area will continue to fall throughout Thursday causing the River Yarty to rise. Riverside property and highway flooding is expected. Minor roads and fords near to and across the river will be impassable. Stock in riverside fields without access to high ground are at risk. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Plym from Shaugh Bridge to Riverside Caravan Park
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall during Storm Ciaran, river levels remain high. Further bands of heavy showers are forecast overnight on the evening of Thursday 2nd November. As catchments are saturated, river levels in the River Plym are expected to rise and remain high overnight.  

Properties and low-lying areas around Coypool Road and Park and Ride, Marsh Close and Marsh Mills Retail Park will start to flood first. 

Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. 

We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout this evening and this message will be updated as the situation changes. Our staff are out in the area and will relay information and assist the emergency services and council.  

This message will be updated by midday on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour due to the rainfall in the last 36hours. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Plan driving routes to avoid the Hammoon road as the gates are locked closed as the road has been affected by flooding.

This flood warning has been removed as river levels are falling. We are continuing to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this warning if required.

River levels have peaked on the River Cam as Storm Ciaran passes through the area.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Cam today, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road at Mill Farm and properties at Queen Camel, West Camel, Bridgehampton and Urgashay.

Scattered showers are forecast overnight and through Friday 03/11/2023. River levels shall remain high at the Weston Bampfylde gauge.

Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.

Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 03/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

River levels are rising on the River Yeo due to Storm Ciaran. Flooding is affecting Mudford Bridge, Parsonage Farm area and properties on Main Street from today, 02/11/2023. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Yeo, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Mudford Bridge, Parsonage Farm area and properties on Main Street. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon. River levels will remain high at the Pen Mill river gauge. Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. We are aware that some river level telemetry data are not appearing or being updated on the gov.uk website. We are sorry about this and are working hard to resolve this as soon as possible. This fault is not affecting our operational response.  Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 03/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flooding is possible throughout the evening on Thursday 2 November and into Friday morning. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall, causing river levels to rise. Further bands of heavy showers are forecast overnight. Catchments are saturated, so river levels will remain high and could respond to further rainfall. Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by midday on Friday or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Taw (Middle) from Taw Bridge to Newnham Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Thursday evening 2nd November.
Heavy rain has fallen in the catchment with showery conditions expected for the next few days. This is causing the River Taw to rise and the river is forecast to continue rising for the next few hours.  
Properties and low lying areas along the River Taw will start to flood first from around 17:30 on Thursday 2nd November. 
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Thursday 2nd November 2023.
Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the catchment. This has meant that the River Exe is now rising and due to peak within the next couple of hours. We expect the river levels to fall overnight.

We expect the river to remain high throughout today though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
